results.title: Economic development
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, Maslyn Williams and Ian Dunlop
results.brief_description: For the people of Papua and New Guinea the time when the family patch of land was the basis of society and the foundation of existence is passing. Commercial agriculture has been introduced and opportunities of wage earning are raising living standards. Main products are copra, coconut oil, coffee, and cocoa. Agricultural research stations have been established by the Administration for the benefit of both white settlers and native growers. Government Co-operative buying has been introduced and the new economic opportunities have enabled the people to become partners with the Administration. The cocoa industry is showing particularly rapid development.

results.title: Economic change in a development country No.2: Wulukum
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Economic Change in a Developing Country”.
Discusses the socio-economic features of Wulukum, a Sepik village in the Torricelli Mountains, North-West New Guinea The film indicates the geographical location of the Wulukum village in the foothills of the Tarricelli Mountains near the Sepik River. It then shows how the changes have so far, provided little reinvestment of income into the village and that more positive changes will be required to stimulate further economic development.

results.title: Economic Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “Film Australia’s Australia”.
Through the sequences in “Economic Australia” students have a rare opportunity to turn back the clock to witness filmmakers’ views of Australia’s economic development. The content focuses on some major events in the economic history of the nation as well as those everyday situations in which economics plays a part in our lives. Presented by Annette Shun Wah.

results.title: Economic anthropology
results.creator_credit: Coast Community College District, Ira R. Abrams and Harry Ratner
results.brief_description:
Episode number 15 of Series “Faces of culture”.
All economics would vanish and all societies would crumble without the labour of men and women. Production, distribution and consumption are the essential components of the economic cycle, even in the most primitive societies. This program looks at the three basic forms of distribution: reciprocity - in which goods are shared between the society, either in a completely unrestricted manner as in hunter-gatherer societies, or in a carefully balanced system of giving of equal gifts. Redistribution often involves the giving away of wealth to gain prestige. Market distribution can be simple, as in local markets where goods are exchanged for other goods or for money, or extremely complicated as in the world systems of capitalism and communism. Narrated by David Carradine.

results.title: Ecology of a hot spring: life at high temperatures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 1. Ecology”.
Uses the hot springs of Yellowstone National Park as a laboratory for the study of organisms that can survive the effects of high temperatures. Suitable for upper secondary level.
